journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Opening and closing of a novel high-speed switching valve

contrib-group.aff: National Key Laboratory of Vehicular Transmission, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *Beijing Institute of Technology, Room 412, Building 9, Beijing 100081, People’s Republic of China. email:wuweijing@bit.edu.cn

abstract.p: The current paper presents a high-speed switching valve for the piston motion control of a single-piston hydraulic free-piston engine. A performance prediction model is developed and a test method for the valve spool movement without using displacement sensors is provided. The agreement between experiments and simulations indicates that the model can predict the valve performance. The valve response is rapid enough for the piston motion control of the engine. The flow capacity of the valve is not reduced by the fast response requirement. The time between the step of the control signal and the response of the pilot valve is important for reducing the valve response lag. A smaller gap is helpful in improving the valve response.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Owing to its potential advantages [1, 2], the free-piston engine (FPE) has been reborn in recent decades. Control of the dual-piston FPE working frequency has been proved difficult since the compression energy for one cylinder is delivered by the combustion energy released in the opposite cylinder [1]. Further, the range of working frequency is narrow [3]. Different from that of the dual-piston FPE, control of the single-piston FPE has a big advantage [4].

The compression ratio, the stroke length, and the working frequency of a single-piston hydraulic free-piston engine (HFPE) can be accurately controlled. The working frequency control of the single-piston HFPE is realized by stopping the piston around bottom dead centre (BDC) between cycles. This control method is called on–off control [4]. The on–off control is a method to improve the effective use of fuel in conventional crank piston engines [5]. However, the method is difficult to realize in conventional crank piston engines. For the single-piston HFPE, the on–off control is easy to achieve. The on–off control hydraulic circuits for the single-piston HFPE, simply called pilot control and direct control, are shown in Fig. 1 [4, 5].

caption.p: On–off control hydraulic circuits for single-piston HFPEs: (a) pilot control; (b) direct control

sec.p: The piston pausing around BDC and the start control of compression strokes can be realized by both of the hydraulic circuits. Both hydraulic circuits comprise a hydraulic accumulator, a check valve, and a switching valve. A high flow capacity and a fast response of the switching valve are needed because of the high piston frequency. However, there is a contradiction between the switching valve flow capacity and its response.

Researchers at the German university Technische Universitët Dresden reported a switching valve for the direct control [1, 6]. Hibi and Ito also used the direct control and no more information about the switching valve was given [5]. Innas BV suggested a novel switching valve configuration used in the pilot control. The theoretical operation characteristics were presented [4]. However, no experimental characteristics were reported since the valve is compact and the sensors are difficult to place properly. Further, the spools have sliding fit with each other. A three-stage servo valve with a rated flow up to 250 l/min at a pressure drop of 7.0 MPa has been used in the pilot control [7]. The three-stage servo valve has satisfied the flow capacity requirement of the single-piston HFPE working frequency control. However, the three-stage servo valve is expensive and its slide-valve design causes a big throttle loss. The current paper presents a high-speed switching valve based on the idea first proposed by Innas BV. It comprises two seat-type valves and a high-speed solenoid valve. The spools of the seat-type valves have no sliding fit with each other. The high-speed solenoid valve acts as a pilot valve. The high-speed switching valve is intended to be used in the pilot control of a single-piston HFPE. A performance prediction model is given and a method for the valve spool movement test is presented. The valve spool dynamics is analysed in detail. The operation characteristics of the valve are investigated by a pulse phase modulation test and a thermodynamic–hydraulic single-piston HFPE model.

sec.title: 2 Physical Model
sec.p: The high-speed switching valve (HSV) configuration based on the concept first proposed by Innas BV is shown in Fig. 2. The design is aimed at satisfying the flow capacity and the response requirements of the single-piston HFPE working frequency control. The HSV comprises a pilot valve and a main valve. The pilot valve is a two-way, three-port, high-speed solenoid valve. The main valve comprises a primary valve and a secondary valve. The primary valve and the secondary valve are both seat-type valves.

In the initial state, the pilot inlet is connected to the pilot outlet. Both the primary valve and the secondary valve are closed, as Fig. 2 shows. There is a small gap between the primary spool and the secondary spool. The gap guarantees that both the primary valve and the secondary valve are closed reliably. The close positions of both spools are determined by seats. The secondary outlet of the secondary valve is connected to the outlet of the primary valve. To achieve a better close response of the HSV, the pressure of the pilot inlet can be set a little higher than the inlet pressure of the main valve.

When the pilot valve connects chamber a and chamber b with the oil tank, the pressures of chamber a and chamber b decrease. With the slow decline of the chamber pressures, the force applied by the inlet pressure of the primary valve raises the primary spool slowly. With the primary valve opening, the hydraulic fluid begins going to the outlet from the inlet. At this stage, the speed of the primary spool is slow because the flow through the pilot valve is limited. An interactive force between the primary spool and the secondary spool appears, due largely to the damping effect of a thin oil layer. When the interactive force is large enough, the secondary valve opens. The secondary inlet is connected to the secondary outlet. Then the primary spool and the secondary spool move together. The chamber pressures decrease dramatically as result of the much higher flow capacity of the secondary valve. At this stage, the spools move much faster than before. The flow area between the inlet and the outlet also becomes larger. Thus, a larger flow capacity and a faster response of the HSV can be achieved. It seems that the HSV opening process includes two stages. The boundary between the two stages is determined by the secondary spool movement. The HSV uses the pilot valve to control the primary spool movement directly at first. The primary spool motion controls the secondary valve opening process. The response of the HSV is guaranteed by both the fast response of the pilot valve and the high flow capacity of the secondary valve. The flow capacity of the HSV is determined by the diameter and the displacement of the primary spool.

sec.title: 3 Mathematical Model
sec.p: A mathematical simulation tool was developed for the HSV performance analysis. To obtain valid results, models of the whole system components used in the HSV prototype test were built. The primary models used in the HSV simulation are presented in this section.

sec.title: 3.1 Hydraulic fluid
sec.p: The dynamic properties of the hydraulic fluid are significant for the hydraulic control system simulation. In the HSV performance simulation, a hydraulic fluid model proposed by Paolo and co-researchers [8] is included. The hydraulic fluid model assumes the air can partially dissolve into the oil. The non-dissolved gas fraction depends on the fluid pressure and it is uniformly mixed with the liquid. The vapour cavitations are also considered in the model. Since the fluid is a mixture of components of different chemical nature, the phase change occurs in a pressure range defined by a higher limit and a lower limit [8]. The oil starts evaporating just below the upper limit and completely finishes when the lower pressure value is reached.

sec.title: 3.2 Main valve
sec.p: The main valve model contains the spool dynamics and the hydraulic chamber dynamics. The spool dynamics present the dynamic characteristics of both the primary spool and the secondary spool, respectively. The hydraulic chamber dynamics are with variable chamber volume and pressure dynamics. The choking effect of the orifice is neglected. Further, the chamber a and the chamber b are called internal chambers.

To describe the spool movements, two coordinates were built, as shown in Fig. 3. The origins of the coordinates were in the valve full closing positions. The positive directions point towards the valve opening directions. The dynamics of the spools are expressed as

sec.title: 3.3 Pilot valve
sec.p: The spool dynamic model of the pilot valve is expressed as a second-order system
in which Xp is the transfer function of the spool displacement, s is the function variable, k is the system constant, ω is the natural frequency, and ξ is the damping ratio.

of the pilot valve is shown in Fig. 4. It is seen that the simulated flow through the pilot valve achieves a high precision. The flows in the pilot valve opening and closing process are calculated by a linear interpolation method [10].

caption.p: Flow versus the pressure drop of the pilot valve

sec.title: 4 Test Apparatus
sec.p: An HSV prototype has been built for the basic characteristic tests. The technical information of the HSV prototype is follows.

list-item.p: Pilot valve: rated pressure is 20 MPa, rated flow is 5 l/min at a pressure drop about 20 MPa, operating voltage is 24 V, and step response time is less than 3.5 ms.
Mass of the primary spool is about 0.045 kg.
Mass of the secondary spool is about 0.04 kg.
HSV outlet diameter is 16 mm, Sm1 is about 73 mm2, Sm2 is about 154 mm2.
Gap between the spools is about 0.1 mm.

sec.p: Figure 5 shows the hydraulic circuit and a photograph of the test apparatus. The hydraulic circuit includes a throttle valve as the load of the HSV prototype. The throttle valve controls the outlet pressure of the HSV prototype. To produce a better performance of the HSV prototype, the pilot inlet pressure is set to be little higher than the inlet pressure of the main valve. The circuit includes three pressure sensors. The inlet, the outlet, and the internal chamber pressures are measured. In the test apparatus, no spool displacement sensor is used because of the compact structure of the HSV. The response of the data-acquisition system is 5000 Hz and the frequency has been applied to all the measured signals individually.

caption.p: The HSV test apparatus: (a) hydraulic circuit; (b) HSV prototype

sec.title: 5.1 Spool dynamics
sec.p: To identify the spool dynamic responses, the dynamic characteristics of the measured pressures are analysed. The measured pressures have some exclusive characteristics as a result of the spool movements. The spool movements are analysed in detail based on the simulated and measured results.

Figure 6 shows the simulated and measured results of the HSV dynamics. It seems that the HSV simulation tool can be used to analyse the HSV operation characteristics. The internal chamber pressure pc decreases as soon as the pilot valve connects the internal chamber with the oil tank, as shown in Fig. 6(a). When the internal chamber pressure becomes small enough, the primary spool opens and sudden pressure changes appear. It seems that a rise of the outlet pressure pm2 appears together with an inlet pressure drop when the primary spool moves. The inlet pressure drop pm1 is a result of the primary valve opening and the instantaneous insufficient supply of the hydraulic oil. When the secondary valve opens, the primary spool moves much faster than before, as shown in Fig. 6(b). The maximum flow area of the HSV is achieved in the valve opening process. In the pilot control of the single-piston HFPE, the maximum flow area of the HSV in the valve opening process is an important design parameter. This is because the HSV only needs to satisfy the flow requirement of the early compression process, as shown in Fig. 1(a). After the valve opening process, the pressures and the spool displacements become stable in the test. The simulated and measured results also indicate that the HSV closing response is rapid.

caption.p: Simulated and measured operation characteristics of the HSV: (a) hydraulic pressures; (b) simulated spool movements

sec.p: Figure 7 zooms in on the HSV opening and closing. It seems that the primary spool goes through an accelerating process and a decelerating process before the secondary spool moves. The resistance on the primary spool is applied by the spool interaction. The spool movements are approximately synchronous after the secondary valve opens. When the HSV is closing, it causes an internal chamber pressure disturbance. After the secondary spool has been seated, the internal chamber pressure increases. Further, the primary spool still moves. The increasing internal chamber pressure makes the primary valve close fast at last. A decrease of the internal chamber pressure appears during the rapid movement of the primary spool. The internal chamber pressure increases again as soon as the primary valve closes. A same trend of the measured internal chamber pressure pc is shown in Fig. 6(a) around 140 ms.

caption.p: Detailed valve spool movements enlarged: (a) opening of the HSV; (b) closing of the HSV

sec.title: 5.2 Action delays
sec.p: Figure 8 shows the component parts of the primary spool motion delay in the valve opening and closing processes. The primary spool motion delay in the valve opening process contains two parts: Δt1 and Δt2, as Fig. 8(a) shows. Δt1 is the transitional period between the step of the pilot valve control signal and the response of the pilot valve. Δt1 is determined mainly by the pilot valve. Δt2 is the transitional period between the response of the pilot valve and the motion of the primary spool. Factors including the rated flow of the pilot valve, the dead volume of the internal chamber, the inlet pressure, and the pilot inlet pressure have effects on Δt2. The effects of the inlet pressure and the pilot inlet pressure are affected by both Sm1 and Sm. In the valve closing process, there are also two motion delay parts, as shown in Fig. 8(b). Δt3 is determined mainly by the pilot valve. Δt4 is the duration of the closing process of the primary valve. It is seen that the transitional period between the step of the pilot valve control signal and the response of the pilot valve plays an important role in the primary spool motion delay. The delay should be further reduced and carefully considered in developing the valve control strategy.

caption.p: Measured response lag of the HSV: (a) measured opening delay; (b) measured closing delay

sec.title: 5.3 Parameter influences
sec.p: Figure 9 gives the simulated operation characteristics of the HSV with different parameters. The effects of different gaps between the spools are shown in Fig. 9(a). It is seen that a smaller gap achieves a higher displacement of the primary spool in the valve opening process. The flow area of the HSV is in direct proportion to the primary spool displacement. Thus, a smaller gap is helpful for the compression stroke of the single-piston HFPE. The dead volume of the internal chamber is a significant factor in the primary spool motion delay as shown in Fig. 9(b). Owing to the high piston frequency of the single-piston HFPE, a shorter motion delay is especially important. Special attention should be paid to reduce the dead volume of the internal chamber.

caption.p: Operation characteristics of the HSV with different parameters: (a) simulated primary spool movements with different gaps; (b) simulated opening process with different dead volumes of the internal chamber; (c) simulated primary spool velocity with different secondary spool diameters

sec.p: The diameter of the primary spool is determined by the flow requirement of the compression stroke. The flow capacity of the secondary valve is guaranteed by the diameter of the secondary spool. Thus, the diameter of the secondary spool determines the response of the HSV. Figure 9(c) shows the effects of different secondary spool diameters. It is seen that the secondary spool diameter determines the primary spool movement at the second stage of the HSV opening process. Further, the rapid response of the HSV is determined mainly by the second stage. The primary spool movement at the first stage in the HSV opening process is determined by the pilot valve. Thus, the valves almost have the same response before the secondary valve opens, as shown in Fig. 9(c).

sec.title: 5.4 Working characteristics
sec.p: To find the working characteristics of the HSV for the single-piston HFPE working frequency control, a pulse phase modulation (PPM) control signal was used to control the HSV. Figure 10 shows the dynamic responses of the measured pressures with a 30 Hz and 5 ms pulse width PPM control signal. It is seen that the special HSV configuration satisfies the response requirement of the single-piston HFPE working frequency control. The advantages of the HSV in the valve opening and closing responses are obvious.

caption.p: Measured operation characteristics of the HSV with PPM signal

sec.p: The simulated results from a single-piston HFPE thermodynamic–hydraulic model combined with the HSV model are shown in Fig. 11. The simulated results from the single-piston HFPE thermodynamic–hydraulic model using a three-stage servo valve (TSV) are also presented. The piston acceleration process during Δt5 is determined mainly by the flow capacity of the valve. It is seen that the HSV has a better performance compared with the TSV. The pressure drop of the HSV is smaller. The smaller pressure drop means less power loss caused by the HSV. Further, the cost of the HSV is much lower than of the TSV.

caption.p: Simulated valve outlet pressure in the working frequency control process

sec.title: 6 Conclusions
sec.p: The design of the HSV that comprises two seat-type valves and a high-speed pilot valve was presented. A performance prediction tool was developed and a method for the valve dynamics test was provided. The dynamics of the HSV were analysed by the simulated and test results. The influences of design parameters on the valve performance were also discussed. The working characteristics of the valve were investigated by the PPM test and the system simulation results.

The HSV opening and closing responses are rapid enough for the single-piston HFPE working frequency control. The flow capability of the primary valve is almost not reduced by the rapid response requirement of the HSV. The transitional period between the step of the control signal and the response of the pilot valve plays an important role in the valve response lag and should be further reduced. A smaller gap is helpful in improving the flow capacity and the response of the HSV. The dead volume of the internal chamber should be strictly limited to reduce the primary spool movement delay. The diameter of the secondary spool determines the response of the HSV. The tested method for the valve dynamics is effective.

Much development work remains before the HSV could be used for the practical working frequency control of the single-piston HFPE. The spool material and the manufacturing process of the valve are important for both reliability and service life as result of the rapid response of the valve. Work on these topics is currently underway at the National Key Laboratory of Vehicular Transmission at the Beijing Institute of Technology.
